case_name: Jai Shanker v. State of Rajasthan

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 576 of 1964 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 11, 1962 of the Rajasthan High Court in S.B. Civil Regulation Second Appeal No. 37 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 576 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 11, 1962 of the Rajasthan High Court in S.B. Civil Regulation Second Appeal No. 37 of 1961.

facts.text: Appellant Jai Shanker was a Head Warder, Central Jail, Jodhpur in 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Jai Shanker, who appeals to this Court by special leave against the judgment of the High Court of Rajasthan dated December 11, 1962, was a Head Warder, Central Jail, Jodhpur in 1950.

facts.text: Jai Shanker started his service as a Warder in April 1940.

anchor.surface_text: He had started his service as a Warder in April 1940, was promoted as Head Warder in 1944 and was a permanent servant of the State.

facts.text: Jai Shanker was promoted as Head Warder in 1944.

anchor.surface_text: was promoted as Head Warder in 1944 and was a permanent servant of the State.

facts.text: Jai Shanker was a permanent servant of the State.

anchor.surface_text: and was a permanent servant of the State.

facts.text: On April 14, 1950 Jai Shanker proceeded on leave for two months ending on June 13, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On Appeal 14, 1950 he proceeded on leave for two months ending on June 13, 1950.

facts.text: Jai Shanker applied for extension of leave on medical grounds for 20 days, then for 10 days, and later for a month.

anchor.surface_text: He applied for extension of leave on medical grounds for 20 days, as he had fallen ill, and again for 10 days. Later he asked for a an extension by a month.

facts.text: Jai Shanker was due to join on August 13, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: He was due to join on August 13, 1950.

facts.text: On August 14, 1950 Jai Shanker was told that no more leave would be granted and that his transfer to Jaipur would not be cancelled.

anchor.surface_text: On August 14, 1950 he was told that numbermore leave would be granted and that his transfer to Jaipur, made while he was ill at Hyderabad, would number be cancelled.

facts.text: Jai Shanker returned to Jodhpur from Hyderabad on September 1, 1950 and applied for further leave.

anchor.surface_text: Jai Shanker returned to Jodhpur from Hyderabad on September 1, 1950 and applied for further leave.

facts.text: Jai Shanker's last application for leave was sent by Registered post with medical certificate on November 3, 1950 asking for leave till November 11, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: He made several applications. His last application was sent by Registered post, supported by a medical certificate, on November 3, 1950 asking for leave till November 11, 1950.

facts.text: No reply was received to Jai Shanker's last and some earlier applications for leave.

anchor.surface_text: To his last and some of the earlier applications for leave he received numberreply

facts.text: On November 8, 1950, Jai Shanker received a communication dated 2/4-11-50 from Deputy Inspector General, Prisons under endorsement from Superintendent, Central Jail, Jodhpur that he was discharged from service from August 13, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: and on November 8, 1950, he received a companymunication dated 2/4-11-50 of the Deputy Inspector General, Prisons under endorsement from the Superintendent, Central Jail, Jodhpur that he was discharged from service from August 13, 1950.

facts.text: Jai Shanker preferred an appeal against the discharge order to the Inspector General of Prisons, Rajasthan which was dismissed on September 24, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: He preferred ail Appeal against that order to the Inspector General of Prisons, Rajasthan but it was dismissed on September 24, 1951.

facts.text: Jai Shanker submitted an appeal to the Home Secretary, Rajasthan Government and was informed by letter dated December 17, 1953 that papers had been sent to Inspector General, Prisons.

anchor.surface_text: Jai Shanker submitted an appeal to the Home Secretary, Rajasthan Government. He, was informed by a letter dated December 17, 1953 from the Home Secretary that the papers had been sent to the Inspector General, Prisons for necessary action.

facts.text: Jai Shanker alleges he was called by Personal Assistant to the Inspector General and offered reinstatement if he undertook not to claim back salary but he declined.

anchor.surface_text: Jai Shanker alleges that he was called by Personal Assistant to the Inspector General and was offered reinstatement if he undertook number to claim back salary but he declined the offer.

facts.text: Jai Shanker served notice under s. 80 CPC and filed suit for declaration that termination illegal as entitled to notice under Art. 311 and back salary of 2369.

anchor.surface_text: After serving a numberice under s. 80 of the Code of Civil Procedure, Jai Shanker filed the suit from which this appeal arises. He asked for a declaration that the termination of his service was illegal inasmuch as he was entitled to a numberice enabling him to show cause against the termination of his service as required by Art. 311 of the Constitution. He also asked for back salary amounting to 2369.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge, Jodhpur held Jai Shanker's allegations about illness true but rejected contention that discharge illegal, disallowed back salary, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge, Jodhpur decided that Jai Shankers allegations about his illness were, true but he rejected the companytention that the discharge from service was illegal. As a companysequence the claim for back salary was disallowed and the suit was ordered to be dismissed.

facts.text: District Judge, Jodhpur reversed trial judge, held Jai Shanker entitled to declaration removal illegal, continued in employment, entitled to arrears of salary.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal to the District Court Jai Shanker succeeded in getting a reversal of the decree of the trial Judge. The District Judge, Jodhpur held that Jai Shanker was entitled to a declaration that his removal from service was illegal and that he companytinued to remain in employment and was also entitled lo all arrears of salary admissible to him under the rules.

facts.text: State Government appealed to Rajasthan High Court which set aside District Judge decree, restored Subordinate Judge decree, ordered Jai Shanker to pay costs.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government appealed against the judgment and decree of the District Judge and by the order under appeal the decree of the District Judge was set aside and the decree of the Subordinate Judge was restored. Jai Shanker was ordered to pay companyts in the High Court and the two companyrts below.

facts.text: No charge was framed against Jai Shanker and he was not given opportunity to show cause.

anchor.surface_text: The short question in this appeal is whether Jai Shanker was entitled to an opportunity to show cause against the proposed punishment as required by cl.  2  of Art. 31 1. It is admitted that numbercharge was framed against him. Nor was he given any opportunity of showing cause.

facts.text: State Government's case is that it did not terminate Jai Shanker's service; he gave up employment by remaining absent.

anchor.surface_text: The case for the State Government is that Government did number terminate Jai Shankers service, and that it was Jai Shanker who gave up the employment by remaining absent.

facts.text: Regulation 13: Individual absent without permission for one month or longer after leave end considered to have sacrificed appointment, reinstated only with sanction.

anchor.surface_text: Regulation 13 is important because it forms the basis of the companytention that Art. 3 1 1 does number apply to this case. That Regulation may be reproduced here An individual who absents himself without permission or who remains absent without permission for one month or longer after the end of his leave should be companysidered to have sacrificed his appointment and may only be reinstated with the sanction of the companypetent authority.

facts.text: Discharge from service by way of punishment amounts to removal from service.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted on behalf of the State Government that discharge from service of an incumbent by way of punishment amounts to removal from service.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Jai Shanker entitled to opportunity to show cause against proposed removal; removal illegal as no opportunity given.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment, Jai Shanker was entitled to an opportunity to show cause against the proposed removal from service on his overstaying his leave and as numbersuch opportunity was to him his removal from service was illegal.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside High Court order, restores District Judge order, remits case to trial Judge for determination of back salary.

anchor.surface_text: He is entitled to this declaration. The order of the High Court must therefore be set aside and that of the District Judge, Jodhpur restored. The question of what back salary is due to Jai Shanker must number be determined by the trial Judge in accordance with the rules applicable, for which purpose there shall be a remit of this case to the civil Judge, Jodhpur.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge decided Jai Shanker's allegations about illness were true.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge, Jodhpur decided that Jai Shankers allegations about his illness were, true

facts.text: Jai Shanker claimed back salary amounting to 2369.

anchor.surface_text: He also asked for back salary amounting to 2369.

facts.text: Appellant permitted to appeal in forma pauperis.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has been permitted to appeal in forma pauperis.

facts.text: State to pay costs of Jai Shanker in Supreme Court, High Court, and two courts below.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government shall pay the companyts of Jai Shanker in this Court, the High Court and the two companyrts below, incurred so far.

arguments.claim: Regulation 13 insufficient to permit removal without opportunity to show cause under Article 311(2)

arguments.claim: Constitutional protection under Article 311 cannot be taken away indirectly by service regulation

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that the companystitutional protection can be taken away in this manner by a side wind. While, on the one hand, there is numbercompulsion on the part of the Government to retain a person in service if he is unfit and deserves dismissal or removal, on the other, a person is entitled to companytinue in service if be wants until his service is terminated in accordance with law. One circumstance deserving removal may be over-staying ones leave.

arguments.claim: Even for overstaying leave, opportunity to show cause required before removal, regardless of regulation framing

anchor.surface_text: This is a fault which may entitle Government in a suitable case to companysider a man as unfit to companytinue in service. But even if a regulation is made, it is necessary that Government should give the person an opportunity of showing cause why he should number be removed. ... A removal is removal and if it is punishment for over-staying ones Leave an opportunity must be given to the person against whom such an order is proposed, numbermatter how the Regulation describes it.

holdings.text: Jai Shanker was entitled to an opportunity to show cause against the proposed removal from service on his overstaying his leave and as no such opportunity was given to him his removal from service was illegal

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment, Jai Shanker was entitled to an opportunity to show cause against the proposed removal from service on his overstaying his leave and as numbersuch opportunity was to him his removal from service was illegal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 311(2) mandates opportunity to show cause before removal even when framed under Regulation 13 as automatic sacrifice of appointment for overstaying leave; action was punitive termination without hearing

holdings.text: Regulation 13 is not sufficient to enable the Government to remove a person from service without giving him an opportunity of showing cause against that punishment

anchor.surface_text: we have, therefore, to determine whether this Regulation is sufficient to enable the Government to remove a person from service without giving him an opportunity of showing cause against that punishment, if any. It is admitted on

holdings.reasoning_summary: Service regulation cannot override constitutional requirement under Art. 311(2); removal for overstaying still requires hearing regardless of regulatory language

holdings.text: Discharge from service of an incumbent by way of punishment amounts to removal from service

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted on behalf of the State Government that discharge from service of an incumbent by way of punishment amounts to removal from service.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit admission by State accepted by court; applies to termination under Regulation 13 which is punitive

holdings.text: Constitutional protection under Art. 311 cannot be taken away by a service regulation in this manner by a side wind

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, contended that under the Regulation all that Government does, is not to allow the person to be reinstated. Government does not order his removal because the incumbent himself gives up the employment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Regulation 13 purporting automatic termination cannot bypass Art. 311 protections; government cannot indirectly defeat constitutional rights through rules

holdings.text: A removal is removal and if it is punishment for over-staying one's leave an opportunity must be given to the person against whom such an order is proposed, no matter how the Regulation describes it

anchor.surface_text: It may be convenient to describe him as seeking reinstatement but this is not tantamount to saying that because the person will only be reinstated by an appropriate authority, that the removal is automatic and outside the protection of Art. 311.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even if absence leads to deemed sacrifice under regulation, it constitutes punitive removal requiring prior opportunity under Art. 311(2); regulatory description irrelevant

holdings.text: Jai Shanker is entitled to a declaration that his removal from service was illegal

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of Art. 311 violation to facts; no opportunity given renders specific termination illegal
